item.title: Button size
item.dc:creator: @n10si_t n10si t
item.description:
@n10si_t wrote:

Pwnd:

Or just use a better layout manager. I actually prefer not using one (null), but I know what it’s downsides are.

That’s what I’m doing now. Will someone help me with something completely irrelevant to this topic bc I have solved my other problem.

I need some help adding an ActionListener to a button.

Here’s the one error I’m getting:

.\Frame.java:38: addActionListener(java.awt.event.ActionListener) in javax.swing
.AbstractButton cannot be applied to (Frame)
                button2.addActionListener(this);
                       ^
1 error
Press any key to continue . . .

Here’s my Frame.java:

import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.*;

import javax.swing.*;


public class Frame extends JFrame {


	public Frame() {

		super("Java");
                JButton button=new JButton("Go Left");
		JButton button1=new JButton("Go Right");
		JButton button2=new JButton("Go Forward");
		JButton button3=new JButton("Go Backward");
		setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
		//addWindowListener(this);
		
		setLayout(null);

	    	setSize(500, 500);
		setBackground(Color.red);

		add(button);
		add(button1);
		add(button2);
		add(button3);

		button.setSize(100, 32);
		button.setLocation(75, 200);

		button1.setSize(100, 32);
		button1.setLocation(315, 200);

		button2.setSize(100, 32);
		button2.setLocation(196, 130);
		button2.addActionListener(this);

		button3.setSize(110, 32);
		button3.setLocation(191, 260);
	
                setVisible(true);
		setResizable(false);
		
        }

	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		Forward.goForward();
	}

}

item.title: Button size
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Or just use a better layout manager. I actually prefer not using one (null), but I know what it’s downsides are.

Read full topic

item.title: Button size
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

In a layout manager, it will (usually) take up the largest amount of space it can in its super container. So if you need to add more components, just add them to the JPanel, and everything will adjust accordingly.

Read full topic

item.title: Button size
item.dc:creator: @n10si_t n10si t
item.description:
@n10si_t wrote:

Davidi2:

Also, you extend JFrame, why do you make another JFrame object?

What do you mean? And also, I’m getting this, no matter what I change the sizes too.

Read full topic

item.title: Button size
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

This is object oriented programming. You are creating a JPanel object, adding the buttons to it, and then placing that same JPanel on the JFrame.

Change
frame.add(new JPanel());
to
frame.add(compsToExperiment);

Also, you extend JFrame, why do you make another JFrame object?

Read full topic

item.title: Button size
item.dc:creator: @n10si_t n10si t
item.description:
@n10si_t wrote:

Davidi2:

Did you ever add the Jpanel to the frame?

… Still getting a blank GUI though.


import java.awt.*;

import javax.swing.*;


public class JavaStuff extends JFrame {


	public JavaStuff() {

		JFrame frame=new JFrame("Java");
                JButton button=new JButton("Left");
		JButton button1=new JButton("Right");
		JPanel panel=new JPanel();

		final JPanel compsToExperiment = new JPanel();

		GridLayout layout = new GridLayout(0,2);
		compsToExperiment.setLayout(layout);

	    	frame.setSize(500, 500);
		frame.setBackground(Color.red);
                frame.add(new JPanel());

		compsToExperiment.add(new JButton("Left"));
		compsToExperiment.add(new JButton("Right"));

		button.setSize(15, 15);
		button.setLocation(25, 25);
		button1.setSize(15, 15);
		button1.setLocation(75, 75);

		panel.setSize(100, 100);
                
                frame.setVisible(true);
		button.setVisible(true);
		panel.setVisible(true);
        }



        public static void main(String[] args) {

		new JavaStuff();
                
        }










}

item.title: Button size
item.dc:creator: @n10si_t n10si t
item.description:
@n10si_t wrote:

My “Right” button is taking up the entire frame.

EDIT: Sorry about the wrong section.

public JavaStuff() {

		JFrame frame=new JFrame("Java");
                JButton button=new JButton("Left");
		JButton button1=new JButton("Right");
		JPanel panel=new JPanel();
	
                frame.setSize(500, 500);
		frame.setBackground(Color.red);
		frame.add(new JButton("Left"));
		frame.add(new JButton("Right"));

		button.setSize(20, 20);
                button.setLocation(25, 25);
		button1.setSize(20, 20);
                button1.setLocation(75, 75);

		panel.setSize(100, 100);
                
                frame.setVisible(true);
		button.setVisible(true);
		panel.setVisible(true);
        }
